bestBHT.bht: The whole multitude cried out together, demanding the immediate removal of this man. They cried out in a most clamorous way, as if they were a single voice. They exclaimed that Jesus should be sent away, to the cross, as he was unworthy to live. Meanwhile, they advocated for the release of Barabbas.

Marvin Vincent: All together [παμπληθει] . The whole multitude [τληθος] of them. Only here in New Testament.
Away [αιρε] . Lit., take away. Compare Acts 21:36; Acts 22:22.
Archibald T. Robertson: All together (πανπληθε). An adverb from the adjective πανπληθης, all together. Used by Dio Cassius. Only here in the N.T."
Away (αιρε). Present active imperative, Take him on away and keep him away as in Acts 21:36; Acts 22:22, of Paul."
But release (απολυσον) is first aorist active imperative, do it now and at once.
John Gill: And they cried out all at once... in a most clamorous way, cried out, as one man, immediately."
Saying, away with this man; to the cross; to Calvary, the place of execution; away with him out of the world; he is not fit to live."

bhtAttempts.bht: The whole multitude came together and cried out in a most clamorous way, as one man, to take away this man. They were demanding that he be taken away, to the cross, to Calvary, out of the world, as he was not fit to live. They wanted him gone and released Barabbas instead.

The whole multitude of them cried out together, demanding that this man be taken away, just as in the case of Paul in Acts 21:36 and Acts 22:22. Their clamorous cry was unanimous, as if they were a single voice, and it was a resounding call for Jesus to be removed from their presence. They declared that he should be sent to the cross, to Calvary, the place of execution, as he was unworthy to live. In contrast, they requested the release of Barabbas instead.

The whole multitude cried out together, demanding the immediate removal of this man. They cried out in a most clamorous way, as if they were a single voice. They exclaimed that Jesus should be sent away, to the cross, as he was unworthy to live. Meanwhile, they advocated for the release of Barabbas.

The crowd, all together, cried out, Away! This expression, all together, is used only here in the New Testament. They wanted this man taken away, perhaps to the cross or out of the world. They were demanding his release, proclaiming, and release unto us Barabbas.

The whole multitude cried out together, demanding that this man be taken away. They were united in their clamorous outcry, immediately calling for his removal, shouting, Away with this man! They wanted him to be taken to the cross, to Calvary, where they believed he deserved to die. In contrast to their demand for this man to be taken away, they also cried out for the release of Barabbas.
